description.en: The aim of the course is to provide participants with an overview of the key issues of research integrity: making decisions about the authorship of a scientific publication in multi-author publications, obtaining informed consent, processing data, ensuring the protection of privacy and personal data of the subjects involved in the study, obtaining necessary permissions, consents and ethics committee approvals for research and understanding their meaning. The entire course is supported by an e-learning environment that brings together materials that are relevant to different fields of science. From them, the doctoral student chooses 6 EAP worth of assignments. The course is structured in such a way that doctoral students can choose topics and tasks appropriate for their specialty and specifics of research there. The course also includes seminars where doctoral students from different disciplines can experience disciplinary differences in interpreting the Code of Conduct for Research Integrity.
description.et:
Kursuse eesmärk on anda osavõtjatele ülevaade hea teaduse võtmeküsimustest: teaduspublikatsiooni autorsuse kokkuleppimine mitme autoriga publikatsiooni korral, teavitatud nõusoleku küsimine, andmete töötlemine, uuringusse kaasatud inimeste privaatsuse ja isikuandmete kaitse tagamine, teadustööks vajalike lubade, nõusolekute ja eetikakomitee kooskõlastuste sisu ja taotlemine.
Kogu kursust toetab eesti- ja ingliskeelne e-keskkond, mis koondab erinevate teadusvaldkondade jaoks olulist materjali, mille hulgast doktorant valib enda jaoks õppeülesanded 6 EAP mahus.
Kursus on ehitatud üles nii, et vastavalt eriala ja uurimistöö spetsiifikale saavad doktorandid valida enda jaoks sobivad teemad ja ülesanded. Kursusel on seminarid, kus erinevate erialade doktorandid saavad kogeda hea teadustava tõlgendamisel distsiplinaarseid erinevusi.

objectives.en: Science is a collective activity based on trust. To ensure credibility, researchers should understand their responsibility. This presupposes that researchers know ethical principles and are capable to notice moral choices in scientific research and to make reasoned decisions. On November 1st, 2017, the University of Tartu together with 20 other Estonian research institutions, the Estonian Research Council, and the Ministry of Education and Research signed the Estonian Code of Conduct for Research Integrity Agreement https://www.eetika.ee/et/estonian-code-conduct-research-integrity. The course gives all doctoral students of the University of Tartu an opportunity to learn in depth about the values and principles of action that underlie research integrity. The course addresses all aspects of research - from the research planning and conduct of research, to the publication of results and their societal application. It also discusses the relationship between the researcher and society and the various roles of the researcher, such as lecturer, supervisor, reviewer, expert, and cooperation partner, as well as dilemmas arising from these roles.
objectives.et: Teadus on kollektiivne tegevus, mis põhineb usaldusel. Usaldusväärsuse tagamiseks on vaja, et teadlased tunnetaksid oma vastutust, mis eeldab aga, et tuntakse eetilisi põhimõtteid, osatakse märgata teadustöös ettetulevaid moraalseid valikukohti ja teha põhjendatud otsuseid. Tartu Ülikool kirjutas 1. 11. 2017 koos 20 teise Eesti teadusasutuse, Haridus- ja Teadusministeeriumi ning Eesti Teadusagentuuriga alla hea teadustava kokkuleppele: https://www.eetika.ee/et/eesti-hea-teadustava. Käesolev kursus annab kõigile TÜ doktorantidele võimaluse tutvuda süvitsi hea teaduse aluseks olevate väärtuste ning tegevuspõhimõtetega, käsitledes teadustöö tegemise kõiki osi - alates teadustöö kavandamisest, teadustöö läbiviimisest kuni tulemuste avaldamise ja rakendamiseni ühiskonnas. Samuti käsitletakse teadlase ja ühiskonna suhteid ning teadlase erinevaid rolle, nt õpetaja, juhendaja, retsensendi, eksperdi ja koostööpartnerina, ning neist tulenevaid dilemmasid.

learning_outcomes.en: The doctoral student who has completed the course has an overview of the values and principles of action that underpin the Code of Conduct for Research Integrity and is capable of identifying occasions when ethical consideration is required in research practice. The student who has completed the course is able to participate in interdisciplinary teamwork, is capable to analyze cases and to reflect critically upon and weigh arguments used in respective analyses. The student is able to recognize his/her attitudes concerning research integrity; the student has expressed his/her views both orally and in writing, has submitted a written assignment that satisfies the course requirements, and is able to make reasoned moral decisions.
learning_outcomes.et: Kursuse läbinud doktorant omab ülevaadet hea teadustava aluseks olevatest väärtustest ja tegevuspõhimõtetest, oskab näha teadustöös ette tulevaid kaalutluskohti. Kursuse läbinu on võimeline osalema interdistsiplinaarses meeskonnatöös, oskab juhtumeid analüüsida ning suudab kriitiliselt reflekteerida ja kaaluda argumente, mida vastavates analüüsides kasutatakse, teadvustab enda hoiakuid hea teaduse (research integrity) valdkonnas: on avaldanud oma arvamust nii suuliselt kui kirjalikult, on sooritanud nõuetekohase kvaliteediga kirjaliku töö ja oskab teha põhjendatud moraaliotsuseid.

notes.et:
Course will be held 100% online in Moodle. That means independent work in Moodle and also attending of six online seminars that take place on particular fixed times every other week. During a independent learning week, doctoral students watch short interactive video lectures, answer questions about the lectures and read one thematic article. By the end of this week of independent work, written question(s) need to be submitted to the lecturer(s) conducting the online seminar during the next week. The seminar week follows the independent learning week. This cycle of an independent learning week followed by a seminar week is repeated throughout the course. The seminars are partially designed following the method of flipped classroom, where learners acquire information independently and during the online seminars particular texts and students' questions are discussed.

The course is supported by the University of Tartu ASTRA Project PER ASPERA, financed by the European Regional Development Fund.

independent_work.et:
* Attending all seminars.
* Watching short video lectures and answering questions about these.
* Reading seminar texts and posting a written assignment in the study forum.

description.et:
Introductory online lecture in Zoom at 14.15-15.00 with Margit Sutrop and Kertu Rajando.
Zoom link: https://ut-ee.zoom.us/j/93253831395?pwd=qh0LB0IxkwwJaAMC3anZOGxAE4g0DE.1

After the introductory lecture you are expected to watch two video lectures by yourself:
- Margit Sutrop: Science and values. Ethics in science and ethics of the scientist. What is research integrity?
- Endla Lõhkivi: What is science? Scientific world picture. Research disciplines, cultures, interdisciplinarity.

Ethical issues related to the design and conduct of research and application of research results. Human studies.
During an e-learning week, doctoral students watch short interactive video lectures (out of six short lectures, three are required), answer questions about the lectures and read one thematic article. By the end of this week of e-learning and independent work, written assignment and question(s) need to be submitted to the study forum in Moodle.
The seminar week follows the e-learning week. This cycle of an independent learning week followed by a seminar week is repeated throughout the course. Each seminar starts with a discussion of 1-2 dilemmas (thematic cases gathered from real life). The seminars are partially designed following the method of flipped classroom, where learners acquire information independently, including through e-learning, and during the seminar meetings only the text read and the questions raised are discussed.

Online seminar in Zoom at 14.15-17.45 with Kadri Tamme.
Zoom link: https://ut-ee.zoom.us/j/98382749822?pwd=QX3vTwrrJcI1AbcKgUM0jYPm7vAbKy.1

Ethical issues related to the planning and conduct of research and application of research results. Topics covered: ethical requirements for research involving human subjects. Selection of subjects, inclusion and exclusion criteria, participant recruitment; informed consent, its exceptions and special forms; privacy protection, risk assessment and minimization, incidental findings, benefit sharing, vulnerable groups, impact analysis. Ethics committee approval.  Obtaining necessary permissions. Ethical issues related to stem cells and cloning.
E-learning, video lectures. Data processing and the protection of personal data when conducting research.

Online seminar in Zoom at 14.15-17.45 with Marju Lauristin.
Zoom link: https://ut-ee.zoom.us/j/92053258600?pwd=9bTaG2Spr3PsQ1OXQtVzLED0dxwabo.1

Data processing and the protection of personal data when conducting research. European and Estonian data protection regulations. Data collection, storage, sharing, processing. Privacy and confidentiality protection. Use of personalized and non-personalized big data in the context of information society. Using public domain data.
E-learning, video lectures. Open science, open data and FAIR data.

Online seminar in Zoom at 14.15-17.45 with Tiiu Tarkpea.
Zoom link: https://ut-ee.zoom.us/j/97776142176?pwd=uTtMiqEa48Naou6Za43GGs0e8hlH4i.1

Open science, open data and FAIR data.
E-learning, video lectures. Authorship and publishing. Problems of defining and protecting intellectual property in science.

Online seminars in Zoom at 14.15-17.45 with Anu Tammeleht and Urmas Sutrop.
Zoom link: https://ut-ee.zoom.us/j/96232585289?pwd=tGQwuNu8nWWbp2AVQFGHA3hTcWeSvo.1

Authorship and publishing. Misconduct and unacceptable practices (plagiarism, inaccurate referencing, self-plagiarism, etc). Problems of defining and protecting intellectual property in science. Publication of research results. Publishing and peer-reviewing. Who is the author of a scientific publication, making decisions in the case of joint authorship. Misconduct and unacceptable practices (plagiarism, inaccurate referencing, self-plagiarism, etc.). Research results (works, data, inventions, know-how) that are protected by IP.
E-learning, video lectures. Loyalty, conflict of interest and different roles of the researcher.

Online seminar in Zoom at 14.15-17.45 with Halliki Harro-Loit.
Zoom link: https://ut-ee.zoom.us/j/91673920080?pwd=UwOJWi0UZw63XkrNIxSXO398wuUl2c.1

Loyalty, conflict of interest and different roles of the researcher. The conflict of loyalty and interest is a matter for both legal and ethical discourse. The rationale for legal discourse is the prevention of corruption. The moral discourse approaches conflicts as a violation of moral obligations. The relevant normative documents are introduced and solutions for various possible conflicts concerning peer review, allocation of resources, and promotion are discussed. The purpose of the discussion of loyalty conflicts is to understand the obligations and the freedom of choice or its limitations that different roles (student, faculty, scientist, leader, citizen, family member) bring with them.
E-learning, video lectures. The Code of Conduct for Research Integrity; misconduct in science.

Online seminars in Zoom at 14.15-17.45 with Mari-Liisa Parder and Kadri Simm.
Zoom link: https://ut-ee.zoom.us/j/95449251593?pwd=l1nwzRFzXSZBN7Rmdqyr1nYFeNe14q.1

The Code of Conduct for Research Integrity and misconduct in science.

audience.et: Doctoral students from all programs, MA students interested in research integrity. No prerequisites.
